header.title: 776 1/2: Tables of Correspondences for Practical Ceremonial
header.category: Western Esotericism, Qabalah, Ceremonial Magic, Occultism, Thelema

central_thesis: This book serves as a practical, reorganized, and expanded version of Aleister Crowley's '777', designed specifically to aid ceremonial magicians in the practical application of qabalistic correspondences for ritual design and performance. It aims to make the vast array of occult data more accessible and functional for operative magick, integrating updated attributions and new material within a Thelemic framework.

structure_content.summary: Explains the book's purpose: to reorganize, expand, and update Aleister Crowley's '777' into a user-friendly format for practical ceremonial magick. It addresses the original '777's lack of practicality, introduces new tables, and updates existing information, emphasizing a shift from theoretical compilation to practical application. It advises the reader to have a basic familiarity with Qabalah and alphabets.

structure_content.chapter_title: Definitions of the Tree of Life
structure_content.summary: Presents core qabalistic attributions, including the Sword & the Serpent, Hebrew names of numbers & letters and their English translations, the Tree of Life planes, Yetziratic attributions, Mystic Numbers, Hebrew and Greek alphabets with numerical values, and various esoteric alphabets (Flame, Passing the River, Celestial Writing, Malachim/Angelic, The Magi, Enochian). It also lists 'Magical Powers & Mystical States' corresponding to the Sephiroth and Paths.

Details four systems of color correspondences for the Tree of Life (King, Queen, Prince, Princess scales). These scales provide visual and vibratory attunements for each Sephirah and Path, with revisions based on Frater A.H.'s investigations for greater accuracy and magical efficacy in practical ceremonial work.

Catalogs divine names, archangels, and magical images relevant to the Worlds of Atziluth and Briah. It includes 'Divine Names in Assiah', 'Transliterations', 'Archangels of Assiah', 'Magical Images of the Sephiroth', '32 Paths of Wisdom' (Hebrew & English translations), 'Magical Formulæ (Greek Atziluthic Words of Power)', and 'Archons (Greek Briatic Names)', providing essential invocational tools.

Lists angelic and elemental hierarchies and names specifically associated with the World of Yetzirah, including 'Angelic Choirs in Assiah', 'Kouroi (Powers & Intelligences - Greek Yetziratic Names)', 'Eudaimones (Spirits - Greek Yetziratic Names)', 'Planetary Angels, Intelligences, and Spirits' (including Olympic Spirits and Genii of the 22 Paths), 'Angels Ruling Signs' (and Decanates), and 'Rulers & Kings of the Elemental Spirits'.

Provides correspondences for the most material Qabalistic World, Assiah. This chapter details 'Heavens of Assiah', 'Latin & English Translations', 'Elements (with Planetary Rulers)', and 'The Ten Earths in Seven Palaces', grounding the magical system in the physical and elemental planes.

Outlines the 'Qlippothic Orders & Elemental Demon Kings', their pronunciations and translations, '10 Hells in 7 Palaces', 'Qlippothic Princes', 'Averse Spirits of the 22 Paths', 'The Kings & Dukes of Edom', and detailed 'Goetic Spirits' for each decanate (by Day and Night), providing information on entities encountered in shadow work or banishing rituals.

Compiles lists of deities from various world religions and magical traditions, facilitating cross-cultural magical work. Includes 'Egyptian Deities' (with complete practical attributions), 'Thelemic Deities' (with practical attributions), 'Greek Deities', 'Roman Deities', 'Hindu Deities', 'Scandinavian Deities', 'Assyro-Babylonian Deities', 'Celtic Deities', 'Voudoun Deities', 'Santeria Orishas', and 'Christianity' (Gods, Apostles, Evangelists, Churches).

A broad collection of tangible and symbolic correspondences for practical ritual work. Includes 'Animals (Real & Imaginary)', 'Plants (Real & Imaginary)', 'Precious & Semiprecious Stones', 'Magical Weapons', 'Magical Formulæ', 'Lineal, Geomantic & Pure Number Figures', 'Mineral Drugs', 'Incenses', 'Vegetable Drugs', and 'The Human Body' (Anatomy, Typical Diseases, The Body, Bodily Functions).

structure_content.chapter_title: Sephirothic Hierarchies in the World of Briah
structure_content.summary: Presents divine names, archangels, choirs of angels, and palaces specific to the World of Briah, offering higher-level attributions for advanced ritual work. This chapter includes 'Divine Names', 'Archangels', 'Choirs of Angels', and 'Palaces of Briah' with Latin and English translations, noting these attributions are distinct from other hierarchies.

Outlines the general attributions and esoteric titles of the Tarot, emphasizing its role as a master key to the Hermetic-Qabalistic view of the Universe. It covers 'General Attribution of Tarot', 'Esoteric Titles of Tarot Trumps', and 'Titles & Attributions of Wands, Cups, Swords, Disks', providing a symbolic language for magical operations.

Expands on the Sephiroth with additional correspondences, including the 'Revolution of YHVH in Briah, Yetzirah, and Assiah', the '42-fold Name', and 'Grades of the Order' (Traditional & Modern Titles, Passwords), offering deeper insights into the nature and manifestation of divine force across the Qabalistic Worlds.

Provides further correspondences related to the elemental forces. It includes 'The Holy Pentagram', 'The Letters of the Pentagrammaton', 'Element Corresponding', 'The Five Senses', 'The Five Rivers', 'The Four Quarters', 'The Four Worlds' (with meaning, spelling, secret numbers & names), and 'The Five Tattwas', linking various symbolic systems to elemental magic.

Offers additional layers of planetary correspondences. It includes 'The Holy Hexagram', 'The Unicursal Hexagram', 'The Planets & Their Numbers', 'The Seven Metals', 'The Seven Chakras' (with anatomy & sacraments), and various 'Planetary Numbers' (x, x², Σ(0-x²), [(Σ(0-x²)/x)], Σ(0-x)), providing a rich symbolic context for planetary magic.

Details further correspondences for the zodiacal signs, which are crucial for astrological magic. This chapter includes 'Signs of the Zodiac', 'Planets Ruling the Signs', 'Planets Exalted in the Signs', and 'The 12 Tribes of Israel', connecting celestial influences to practical work.

Explores the psychological dimensions of the Qabalah. It covers 'Parts of the Soul' (Hebrew, English, Egyptian, Hindu), 'The Ten Fetters, or Sanyoganas (Buddhism)', 'Meaning of Col. 1505', 'Transcendental Morality' (Virtues, Sins, Magick Powers), and 'Psychological Attributions', linking internal states and spiritual development to the qabalistic framework.

Provides detailed explanatory notes for specific entries within the tables, clarifying meanings, historical context, alternative names, and interpretive insights. These notes are critical for understanding the nuances of the correspondences and the editorial decisions made in '776 1/2', particularly regarding problematic attributions from earlier versions of '777'.

Offers a systematic method for designing and implementing magical rituals, encompassing 'The Five Preliminaries' (Purpose, Principle, Preparation of Person & Place, Timing, The Magical Link) and 'The Six Ceremonial Phases' (Ayin/Circle, Kether/Lamp, Chokmah/Lance, Binah/Grail, Middle Pillar/Sword, Malkuth/Stone). It emphasizes personal creativity, ethical considerations, and practical execution, providing a framework for creating effective magical operations.

Presents ten complete sample rituals, each illustrating the application of the book's principles for different magical objectives (e.g., generating magical force, understanding magick, protection, purifying character, establishing the Law of Thelema). These rituals serve as practical examples and templates, demonstrating how to integrate the correspondences and ritual phases into a coherent magical working.

Contains instructions for commonly used banishing and invoking rituals. This includes 'The Signs of the Grades', 'The Middle Pillar Ritual', 'The Lesser Ritual of the Pentagram', 'The Lesser Ritual of the Hexagram', 'The Greater Ritual of the Hexagram', 'The Star Ruby', 'The Star Sapphire', 'Liber Pleiades', 'The General Exordium, Particular Exordium & Rosicrucian Prayer', and 'The Prayers of the Elementals', providing fundamental tools for practical ceremonial magic.

key_concepts.definition: A 36-line system derived from the Qabalistic Tree of Life, used as the primary organizational structure to arrange all tables of correspondences in the book, allowing for quick cross-referencing for ritual design.

The four Qabalistic Worlds—Atziluth (Archetypal/Deity), Briah (Creative/Archangelic), Yetzirah (Formative/Angels), and Assiah (Action/Material/Matter &c.)—which represent different planes of existence and manifestation, each with specific hierarchies and attributions for magical operations.

The mechanism by which a magical ceremony's intent is connected to its desired result, often through the magician themselves, a consecrated object (e.g., talisman, eucharist), or specific actions that 'ground' the invoked forces into the chosen plane of manifestation.

A structured preparatory phase for ritual design, comprising: 1. Purpose (Clear Definition, Moral Considerations, Creative Visualization, Taking Action, Confronting the Shadow), 2. Principle (Path, Pantheon, Correspondences), 3. Preparation of Person & Place, 4. Timing (Annual, Monthly, Weekly, Diurnal tides, Tattwas), and 5. The Magical Link.

A ritual execution model mapped to the Tree of Life: 0. Ayin (Banishing & Purification), 1. Kether (General Invocation), 2. Chokmah (Oath or Proclamation), 3. Binah (Specific Invocation), Middle Pillar (Descent of Power from Binah to Malkuth), and 10. Malkuth (Perfecting the Magical Link & Concluding).

An Eastern system of five elements (Akasha, Vayu, Tejas, Apas, Prithivi), each with specific daily tidal patterns, utilized for precise timing of magical operations to align with favorable energetic flows.
Aleister Crowley's foundational qabalistic dictionary of correspondences, which '776 1/2' aims to surpass in practicality, organization, and updated/expanded content for modern ceremonial magic.

The 'Shells' or averse spirits, representing the unbalanced, chaotic, or destructive aspects of the Tree of Life, including various demon kings and goetic spirits, which are often addressed in banishing or shadow work.

The central spiritual task in Thelemic magic, representing the attainment of 'Knowledge & Conversation' with one's true divine self or higher genius, considered the ultimate lawful purpose of all magical operations.

A meditative technique using the four Color Scales (King, Queen, Prince, Princess) to attune consciousness to specific Qabalistic Paths or Sephiroth. The practitioner visualizes themselves transitioning through these colors to ascend or descend the Tree of Life, evoking strong feeling responses.

practical_system.description: The book presents a comprehensive system for ceremonial magic rooted in Qabalah, designed for practical application. It integrates a vast array of correspondences across the Four Worlds, enabling magicians to attune their consciousness to specific divine, angelic, planetary, or elemental principles. Ritual construction follows a 'Five Preliminaries' and 'Six Ceremonial Phases' model, guiding practitioners through defining purpose, selecting principles and pantheons, preparing self and space, timing, establishing magical links, and executing the ritual climax to manifest desired changes. Emphasis is placed on ethical considerations, creative visualization, assumption of god-forms, vibration of divine names, and integrating the magical experience into daily life and personal growth.
tools: Qabalistic Tree of Life (as conceptual framework)

Tables of Correspondences (Divine Names, Angelic Choirs, Planetary Intelligences/Spirits, Elemental Rulers, Pantheons, Stones, Incenses, Drugs, Human Body attributions, Tarot Trumps/Cards, Alphabets, Chakras, Tattwas, etc.)
Magical Weapons (Wand, Cup, Sword, Pentacle, Lamen, Censer, Altar, Magical Circle & Triangle)
Divine Names and Magical Formulæ (for vibration and invocation)
Magical Journal (for recording operations and self-reflection)
Color Scales ('The Ladders' method for attunement)
Bell (for marking ritual phases and battery of knocks)
rituals: Liber O: Basic Method (A:.A:. Document)
Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Pentagram (LBRP)
Lesser Banishing Ritual of the Hexagram (LBRH)
Middle Pillar Ritual
Greater Invoking Hexagram Ritual
The Star Ruby (Banishing)
The Star Sapphire (Invoking)
Liber Pleiades
The General Exordium, Particular Exordium & Rosicrucian Prayer
The Prayers of the Elementals (Gnomes, Sylphs, Undines, Salamanders)
Sample Ritual #1: Generation of Magical Force
Sample Ritual #2: Wisdom in the Practice of Magick (Liber Israfel adaptation)
Sample Ritual #3: Health & Prosperity of the Order
Sample Ritual #4: Ease of Circumstances (Candle Magic)
Sample Ritual #5: Magical Protection: A Bodyguard of Invisible Warriors
Sample Ritual #6: Knowledge & Conversation of the Holy Guardian Angel (Ritual VIII)
Sample Ritual #7: Devotion to the Divine
Sample Ritual #8: Insight Into Nature: The Art of Evocation
Sample Ritual #9: Purifying the Character
Sample Ritual #10: Establishing the Law of Thelema: The Thelemic Mass

relevant_quotes.text: 776½ is not quite 777. Aleister Crowley's book 777 has been a standard magical reference for three-quarters of a century. Its original purpose, as expressed in its full Latin subtitle, was Prolegomena Symbolica ad Systemam Sceptico-Mysticæ Viræ Explicandæ, Fundamentum Hieroglyphicum Sanctissimorum Scientiæ Summæ; that is, 'A Compilation of Symbols, Towards a Systematisation of the Skeptical-Mystical Way Set Forth: A Hieroglyphic Foundation of the Most Holy Things of the Higher Knowledge.' ...Our present efforts, be assured, are reflective of a somewhat lesser grade. Furthermore, our purpose is very different from Crowley's purpose in 1906. Our intent is to support the practice of ceremonial magick, pure and simple.

What has been done with the present work is to resequence the most practical of these ten score tabulations so that they are more functional in actual ceremonial design. Additional information has been added that was not included in 777. Other information has been updated, supplemented, or modified.
Every number is infinite; there is no difference.
Wisdom says: be strong! Then canst thou bear more joy.
Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law.

The true 'occult [that is, hidden] meaning' of this letter was not then to be disclosed! Even at such an early date, it was thus recorded in the primary foundation literature of the Qabalah that the true significance of Tzaddi was not what it was suspected to be.

There is no one 'right way' to design and perform magick ritual – although there are plenty of wrong ways! Magick is inherently creative. At its best, it is a dynamic expression of the hidden genius of the magician.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant for practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly within the Golden Dawn and Thelemic traditions, as it addresses significant practical limitations of foundational texts like Crowley's '777'. By reorganizing, expanding, and updating correspondences, and integrating a structured approach to ritual design, it serves as a critical bridge between theoretical knowledge and operative ceremonial magic. Its emphasis on clarity, ethical considerations, and personal psychological integration makes it a valuable resource for fostering effective and responsible magical practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of practicing ceremonial magicians, students of Qabalah and Thelema, and those engaged in Hermetic traditions. It is designed to be accessible for novices seeking a structured entry into ritual design while also providing comprehensive and updated reference material for experienced adepts. Researchers in occultism will find its detailed correspondences and contextual notes useful for comparative studies.
